choices.text: Diameter of the main pulmonary artery > 16 mm
Diameter of the left pulmonary artery > 16 mm
Diameter of the descending right pulmonary artery > 16 mm
Diameter of the descending left pulmonary artery > 16 mm

questions.text: What is the objective sign of identifying pulmonary plethora in a chest radiograph? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diameter of the descending right pulmonary artery > 16 mm

 

Explanation:

 

Pulmonary plethora refers to an increased blood flow to the lungs, which can be identified on a chest radiograph. One objective sign of pulmonary plethora is the measurement of the diameter of the descending right pulmonary artery. If the diameter exceeds 16 mm, it is indicative of increased pulmonary blood flow, suggesting pulmonary plethora.

 

The descending right pulmonary artery is a key structure evaluated in chest radiographs when assessing for signs of pulmonary congestion or increased blood flow. Measurements greater than 16 mm suggest that the pulmonary vascular system is under increased pressure or volume, which is a hallmark of pulmonary plethora.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diameter of the main pulmonary artery > 16 mm: While the main pulmonary artery's diameter is relevant in assessing overall pulmonary artery pressure, it is not as specific for identifying pulmonary plethora as the descending right pulmonary artery.


Option B. Diameter of the left pulmonary artery > 16 mm: The left pulmonary artery's diameter is not typically used as a specific indicator for pulmonary plethora on a chest radiograph.


Option D. Diameter of the descending left pulmonary artery > 16 mm: The descending left pulmonary artery is not the standard measurement used to identify pulmonary plethora; the descending right pulmonary artery is preferred for this assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective sign of identifying pulmonary plethora in a chest radiograph is a diameter of the descending right pulmonary artery greater than 16 mm.

questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 10 years

 

The typical time interval from HIV infection to the manifestation of AIDS, in the absence of antiretroviral therapy, is approximately 10 years. This period is often referred to as the latency period, during which the virus is actively replicating in the body, but the immune system has not yet deteriorated to the point of clinical AIDS. This period can vary based on several factors, including the individual's genetic predisposition, co-infections, and overall health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mean interval b/w infection to AIDS is due to prolonged latency period (~10- years).

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Chap 201

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in ABCD2 scoring? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) History of stroke

 

Explanation:

 

The ABCD2 score is used to assess the risk of developing a subsequent stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

 

The components of the ABCD2 score include:

 

  • A (Age): Age 60 years or older scores 1 point.
  • B (Blood Pressure): Systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg or higher, or diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg or higher scores 1 point.
  • C (Clinical Features): Unilateral weakness scores 2 points; speech disturbance without weakness scores 1 point.
  • D (Diabetes): Presence of diabetes scores 1 point.
  • D (Duration of Symptoms): Symptoms lasting 60 minutes or longer score 2 points; symptoms lasting 10-59 minutes score 1 point.

 

History of stroke is not included in the ABCD2 scoring system. Instead, it is a component of other scoring systems, such as the CHADS2 or CHA2DS2-VASc scores, which are used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation and to guide anticoagulation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age: Age 60 years or older is a factor in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option B. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Option C. Diabetes mellitus: The presence of diabetes is included in the ABCD2 score and scores 1 point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ABCD2 score includes age, blood pressure, clinical features, duration of symptoms, and diabetes. History of stroke is not included in this scoring system but is part of other risk assessment tools like CHADS2 and CHA2DS2-VASc

choices.text: Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility
Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility

questions.text:
A chronic cigarette smoker now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below.(INICET MAY 2023)

 

Initial lung volumes were: FEV1 - 0.9L, FVC - 1.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

After bronchodilation: FEV1 - 1.9L, FVC - 3.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obstructive disease with bronchodilator reversibility

 

The pulmonary function test results show a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, consistent with obstructive lung disease. Significant improvement in FEV1 post-bronchodilation indicates reversibility (FEV1 - anything >200ml is significant), suggesting conditions like asthma or COPD with reversible obstruction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Vascular disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Pulmonary function tests do not suggest vascular disease.


Option B. Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Restrictive diseases show reduced volumes but normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio.


Option C. Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility: Not applicable as the patient shows obstructive pattern with reversibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive lung diseases, such as asthma or COPD, may show bronchodilator reversibility.

questions.text: Pancreatic cancer has the highest association with: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jegher’s syndrome

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is significantly associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. PJS is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of benign polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and distinctive pigmented spots on the skin. It is caused by mutations in the STK11 (LKB1) gene. Individuals with PJS have a markedly increased risk of developing several types of cancer, including a 36% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer, which is considerably higher compared to the general population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FAMMM Syndrome: While FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma) syndrome, associated with mutations in the p16/CDKN2A gene, increases the risk for melanoma and pancreatic cancer, its association with pancreatic cancer is not as strong as that seen in PJS.

 

Option B. FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis): FAP, primarily known for its high risk of colorectal cancer, also has some association with other cancers including pancreatic cancer, but again not as high as PJS.

 

Option C. Hereditary pancreatitis: Typically caused by mutations in the PRSS1 gene, hereditary pancreatitis does increase the risk for pancreatic cancer, but the risk is less compared to PJS.


Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic cancer has highest association with Peutz Jeghers syndrome.

 

Hereditary risk factors -

 

  • Peutz Jeghers syndrome- STK 11 (LKB1)
  • Hereditary pancreatitis – PRSS1 / SPIN 11
  • Cystic fibrosis – CFTR
  • FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma)- p16/ CDKN2A
  • Hereditary breast &ovarian cancer- BRCA2
  • HNPCC/ Lynch syndrome – MLH1, MSH2, MSH 6, PMS2

questions.text: Radioactive isotope preferred in a patient with suspected metastatic thyroid cancer for whole body imaging: [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. C) I131

 

Explanation:

 

I131 (Iodine-131) is the preferred radioactive isotope for detecting thyroid cancer metastases because:

  • Thyroid tissue specifically takes up iodine
  • It allows both imaging and treatment (theranostic agent)
  • Long half-life suitable for whole-body imaging
  • High sensitivity for detecting thyroid tissue and metastases
  • Can be administered orally

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. F18-Deoxyglucose: While useful for many cancers, FDG-PET is less specific than I131 for thyroid cancer. It's mainly used for poorly differentiated thyroid cancers that don't concentrate iodine.

 

Option B. Tc99m: While used in thyroid scans, it's mainly for routine thyroid imaging and not as effective for metastatic disease detection compared to I131.

 

Option D. Co60: Used in external beam radiotherapy for cancer treatment, not for diagnostic imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. I131 is the gold standard for detecting well-differentiated thyroid cancer metastases
  2. Understanding the principle of theranostic agents (can be used for both therapy and diagnosis)
  3. Recognizing the importance of tissue-specific tracers in nuclear medicine
  4. Knowledge of different radioisotopes and their clinical applications

questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

 

For a patient presenting with hemodynamically unstable symptoms such as a significantly low blood pressure and a high heart rate, as indicated by a pulse of 180/min and systolic BP of 70 mmHg, immediate DC cardioversion is indicated. This procedure is critical for restoring normal heart rhythm and preventing further cardiovascular compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valsalva Maneuver: it is typically used in stable patients to attempt cardioversion of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) back to a normal rhythm. It is not suitable for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Adenosine: it is effective in terminating certain types of SVT by temporarily blocking the AV node but is used in stable patients. Given the patient's low BP, this is not the first-line approach.

 

Option D. Verapamil: it is a calcium channel blocker used for rate control in cases of SVT, more appropriate for stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DC cardioversion is the emergency treatment of choice for a patient with hemodynamically unstable narrow QRS complex tachycardia, as it quickly restores normal rhythm and stabilizes the patient.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Cardiology/SVT/chap 246

choices.text: It is faster than AV nodal pathway
It is slower than AV nodal pathway

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the bundle of Kent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is slower than AV nodal pathway

 

The false statement about the bundle of Kent is that it is slower than the AV nodal pathway. In fact, the bundle of Kent provides a rapid conduction pathway between the atrium and the ventricle, bypassing the AV node. This pathway allows for faster conduction than the AV nodal pathway due to the nature of the myocardial fibers involved and the lack of delay that normally occurs at the AV node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is faster than the AV nodal pathway: This statement is actually true. The bundle of Kent facilitates faster electrical conduction from the atria to the ventricles by bypassing the slower AV node, contributing to the clinical manifestations of pre-excitation syndromes.

 

Option C. Leads to a short PR interval: This is true. The rapid conduction via the bundle of Kent results in premature activation of the ventricles, reflected as a shortened PR interval on an electrocardiogram.

 

Option D. Leads to a prolonged QRS duration: This is also true. The activation of ventricular myocardium via the accessory pathway occurs in a less synchronized manner compared to normal conduction through the His-Purkinje system, leading to a broader and prolonged QRS complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bundle of Kent is an accessory pathway connecting atrium and ventricle with conduction through Na+ channels leading to bypass of physiological AV conduction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/WPW

questions.text: A female patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. Her vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. Which of the following is used as first-line management to treat the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The patient's ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia. This type of tachycardia, in a stable patient, is initially managed with vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage or the Valsalva maneuver. These maneuvers aim to increase parasympathetic tone and slow conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node. If vagal maneuvers are ineffective or not feasible, the next step is to administer an AV nodal blocker.

 

Adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment for stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia. It works by transiently blocking the AV node, thereby interrupting the re-entrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia. The initial dose of adenosine is 6 mg administered rapidly IV push, followed by a 10 ml saline flush. If the tachycardia persists, additional doses of 12 mg may be given, with a maximum cumulative dose of 30 mg. Adenosine has a very short half-life of approximately 8 to 10 seconds, necessitating rapid (IV push) administration and immediate follow-up with normal saline to ensure efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is used for the treatment of various types of arrhythmias, including wide complex tachycardias (regular and monomorphic rhythm).

 

Option B. DC Cardioversion: Direct current (DC) cardioversion is used in cases of hemodynamic instability or when pharmacological treatment fails. It is not the first-line treatment for a stable patient presenting with regular narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can be used to manage atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm, because in that case adenosine is contraindicated).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia, adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a serious fungal infection that commonly affects immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV. The standard first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis involves an induction therapy phase, typically with a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days. This regimen is effective in reducing the fungal burden and improving outcomes in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vancomycin: This antibiotic is used primarily for bacterial infections, particularly those caused by Gram-positive bacteria. It is not effective against fungal infections such as cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option B. High dose fluconazole: While fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, it is generally used after the initial induction phase with amphotericin B and flucytosine. High dose fluconazole can be part of the consolidation or maintenance therapy.

 

Option C. Voriconazole: This antifungal is primarily used for infections caused by Aspergillus species and is not the preferred treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cryptococcal meningitis in HIV-positive patients, the first-line induction therapy is a combination of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine for at least 14 days.

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MRI imaging is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD) is a rare, genetic, demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by a distinctive "tigroid" pattern on MRI. This pattern arises from the preservation of perivascular myelin in the brain's white matter, interspersed with areas of demyelination, creating a striped or tigroid appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pantothenate kinase deficiency: This condition is also known as PKAN (Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration). It typically shows a characteristic MRI feature known as the "eye of the tiger" sign, which involves a specific pattern of iron deposition in the basal ganglia. The "eye of the tiger" sign appears due to a combination of hyperintense signal surrounded by a region of hypointensity on T2-weighted MRI images, reflecting iron accumulation and gliosis. This is distinct from the tigroid pattern seen in demyelinating diseases.

 

Option B. Neuroferritinopathy: Neuroferritinopathy is another disorder of iron metabolism that affects the brain, leading to iron accumulation, particularly in the basal ganglia. MRI findings in neuroferritinopathy typically do not include the tigroid pattern but may show abnormalities such as signal changes in the basal ganglia related to iron deposition. The imaging features here are more associated with iron accumulation rather than the patchy demyelination that produces the tigroid appearance.

 

Option D. Aceruloplasminemia: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare hereditary disorder characterized by iron accumulation in various tissues, including the brain. Similar to neuroferritinopathy, the primary MRI findings in aceruloplasminemia are related to iron deposition, particularly in the cerebellum and basal ganglia, and do not typically involve the tigroid pattern. Instead, the imaging might show evidence of iron accumulation without the specific changes associated with demyelination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a prototypical condition that displays a tigroid pattern on MRI. This appearance is due to the patchy preservation and destruction of myelin in the white matter, creating alternating areas of normal myelin and demyelination. This results in the characteristic striped or tigroid appearance on imaging studies, reflective of the disease’s impact on myelination.

choices.text: Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.text: Identify the correct match out of the following diuretics and the respective site of action: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

 

Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors: These diuretics inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which is located predominantly in the proximal convoluted tubule. This inhibition reduces the reabsorption of bicarbonate, sodium, and water in this segment, making "Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule" the correct match.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics: These have a diffuse mechanism of action throughout the nephron, primarily affecting water-permeable regions such as the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle. The statement "Osmotic diuretics → Collecting duct" is incorrect as the major sites of action are the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb, not just the collecting duct.

 

Option C. Thiazides: Thiazide diuretics act on the distal convoluted tubule by inhibiting the sodium-chloride transporter. They do not primarily act on the Loop of Henle, making "Thiazides → Loop of Henle" incorrect.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists: These drugs act on the collecting ducts, particularly affecting the principal cells where aldosterone promotes sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion. Therefore, the statement "Aldosterone antagonists → Distal Convoluted tubule" is incorrect as their primary site of action is the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diuretics with their site of action:

 

  • Osmotic diuretics → Proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle
  • Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule
  • Thiazides → Distal convoluted tubule
  • Aldosterone antagonists → Collecting duct

questions.text: Which of the following transplants requires most extensive human leukocyte antigen (HLA) matching to prevent rejection? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kidney

 

Explanation:

 

Kidney transplantation requires the most extensive HLA matching among solid organ transplants because:

  • Kidney tissue is highly immunogenic
  • Poor HLA matching significantly increases rejection risk
  • Better HLA matching correlates with improved long-term graft survival
  • Six antigen match (complete HLA match) shows best outcomes
  • Highly sensitized patients benefit most from close HLA matching

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is relatively tolerant to HLA mismatches and can be transplanted successfully with less stringent matching requirements.

 

Option C. Intestine: While immunologically active, intestinal transplants focus more on ABO compatibility than extensive HLA matching.

 

Option D. Heart: Heart transplants require ABO compatibility but are less dependent on extensive HLA matching compared to kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Understanding the importance of HLA matching in different organ transplants
  2. Recognition that kidney transplants are most sensitive to HLA mismatches
  3. Knowledge that different organs have varying immunological requirements
  4. Appreciation of factors affecting transplant success rates

questions.text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Loss of myelin sheath

 

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is primarily characterized by the autoimmune-mediated demyelination of central nervous system neurons. The myelin sheath is crucial for proper and fast electrical conduction along nerve fibers; it facilitates saltatory conduction, which allows the action potential to jump rapidly from one node of Ranvier to the next. The loss of this myelin sheath in MS results in significantly slowed and disrupted nerve signal conduction, which underlies many of the neurological symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gliosis: Gliosis is not seen in MS but seen in viral encephalitis, Alzheimer's disease, traumatic brain injury, and gliomas

 

Option C. Defect at node of Ranvier: Although alterations in the nodes of Ranvier occur secondary to demyelination, the primary issue is the loss of the myelin sheath itself, not initial defects at the nodes.

 

Option D. Leaky Na+ channel: This option refers to a specific type of channelopathy that isn't characteristic of MS. In MS, the problem is more about the insulation (myelin) around the nerve fibers rather than the ion channels within the nerve cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelination that results in loss of saltatory conduction occurring from one node of Ranvier to the other.

 

Reference - Harrison/Multiple sclerosis/Chap 444

questions.text: A patient with hemolytic anemia presents with index finger pain and chest pain. The patient has Hb of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin in serum. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sickling crisis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with hemolytic anemia, evidenced by a low hemoglobin level of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, indicating hemolysis. The specific symptoms of index finger pain and chest pain are highly suggestive of a sickling crisis.

 

In sickle cell disease, patients may experience episodes of severe pain, known as sickle cell crises or vaso-occlusive crises, due to the blockage of blood flow by sickled red blood cells. The index finger pain (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome) are classic manifestations of such crises. Acute chest syndrome is a severe complication of sickle cell disease that presents with chest pain, fever, and pulmonary infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microangiopathic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells in small blood vessels but does not typically present with the specific symptoms of dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: While thalassemia also causes hemolytic anemia, it does not usually present with dactylitis or acute chest syndrome.

 

Option D. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the immune system attacking red blood cells but lacks the specific signs of sickle cell crisis, such as dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with hemolytic anemia presenting with severe pain in the fingers (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome), sickle cell crisis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the most likely causative organism of ventilator-associated pneumonia among the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acinetobacter.

 

Acinetobacter species are particularly prevalent in hospital settings and are a common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). These organisms are known for their ability to survive on surfaces for extended periods and their resistance to multiple antibiotics, making them a significant concern in intensive care units where patients are often intubated. Acinetobacter, along with Pseudomonas and Stenotrophomonas, is known for colonizing the respiratory tract of ventilated patients, leading to VAP, which typically occurs after 48 hours of mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium: This genus, including species like Clostridium difficile, is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal infections, particularly antibiotic-associated diarrhea, rather than pneumonia.

 

Option B. Klebsiella: While Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause ventilator-associated pneumonia, it is generally less common than Acinetobacter in this specific infection context. Klebsiella tends to be more associated with community-acquired pneumonia and hospital-acquired infections outside of the ventilator context.

 

Option D. Haemophilus: Haemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections but is more commonly linked to community-acquired pneumonia and exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease rather than VAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acinetobacter, pseudomonas, stenotrophomonas, Burkholderia cepacia are common organisms causing VAP. VAP occurs due to colonization by organisms in < 48 hours.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Pneumonia/Chap 142

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ocrelizumab

 

Ocrelizumab is the preferred drug for the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). PPMS is a form of multiple sclerosis characterized by a gradual progression of neurological symptoms without relapses. The reference paragraph highlights that Ocrelizumab is the only drug that has been shown to be effective in treating PPMS based on recent clinical trials. Ocrelizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20-positive B cells, which are believed to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Natalizumab: This drug is used primarily for relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). It works by inhibiting the migration of immune cells into the central nervous system, but it has not been shown to be effective in PPMS.

 

Option C. Fingolimod: While Fingolimod is effective in treating RRMS, it is not the preferred treatment for PPMS. Fingolimod works by modulating sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors to prevent lymphocytes from reaching the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Alemtuzumab: This drug is used for RRMS and works by depleting circulating T and B lymphocytes. It has not been demonstrated to be effective in treating PPMS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocrelizumab is the only drug currently shown to be effective in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS).

 

Remember - The drug that has been shown to be effective in treating secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS) is Siponimod, which is a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor agonist.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

choices.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was admitted complains of dyspnea. On examination he has puffy face, with engorged veins over the chest. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT thorax

 

Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction, suggested by symptoms like dyspnea, facial puffiness, and engorged chest veins, along with a chest X-ray showing mediastinal enlargement, requires further detailed imaging to accurately assess the extent of the obstruction and the presence of any mediastinal masses. A CT scan of the thorax is the most appropriate next step as it provides detailed images of the chest's anatomy, helping to identify the cause of the SVC obstruction, which is crucial for planning appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total blood count with peripheral smear: While useful for general health assessments and diagnosing blood disorders, this does not directly address the structural issues seen in SVC obstruction.

 

Option C. Start cyclophosphamide: Beginning chemotherapy like cyclophosphamide would only be appropriate after a specific diagnosis of a malignancy causing the SVC obstruction, confirmed via imaging and biopsy.

 

Option D. Urgent referral to RT: Referral for radiation therapy (RT) may be necessary if a malignancy is confirmed, but it is premature without a detailed thoracic CT and biopsy if indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT thorax is critical for detailed evaluation in suspected SVC obstruction to confirm the diagnosis and guide further specific treatment, whether surgical, medical, or radiation therapy.

questions.text: Innervation of lateral rectus is by which nerve? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CN VI

 

The lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (abduction), is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This nerve specifically controls the lateral rectus muscle, allowing for the lateral movement of the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CN III (Oculomotor nerve): The oculomotor nerve innervates most of the other extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It is not responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option B. CN IV (Trochlear nerve): The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which is involved in downward and outward movement of the eye. It does not innervate the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option D. CN VII (Facial nerve): The facial nerve is primarily responsible for the muscles of facial expression. It does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the lateral rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve (CN VI), also known as the abducens nerve.

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG was done which showed flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Hypokalemia is a condition characterized by low potassium levels in the blood, which can occur in patients taking diuretics. Diuretics increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to its depletion. The triad of ECG changes associated with hypokalemia are distinctive and include:

 

  1. Flattening of T waves: This is often the earliest change observed in hypokalemia.
  2. Prominent U waves: These waves become more visible as the potassium levels drop further.
  3. ST depression: This can occur in more severe cases of hypokalemia.

 

These ECG changes are due to the altered repolarization of the heart muscle cells caused by low potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia, or high potassium levels, typically presents with different ECG changes, such as tall, peaked T waves, wide QRS complexes, and possibly absent P waves. These findings are not consistent with the patient's ECG.

 

Option C. Hypomagnesemia: While low magnesium can cause ECG changes and muscle weakness, the specific ECG findings in this case (flat T waves and prominent U waves) are more indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels do not typically cause specific ECG changes. Severe hypernatremia might cause cerebral edema and nonspecific T wave inversions, but it does not lead to the characteristic ECG findings seen with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia is characterized by ECG changes such as flattened T waves, prominent U waves, and ST depression. It is commonly seen in patients on diuretics, and recognizing these ECG patterns is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with increased thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination. He has no other symptoms. His random blood sugar was 205 mg/dl, what appropriate investigations should be done? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. HbA1c
  2. Urine ACR
  3. Echocardiography
  4. Fundoscopy
  5. ECG
  6. Serum protein electrophoresis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) i, ii, iv, v

 

The patient presents with hyperglycemia (random blood sugar of 205 mg/dl), indicating diabetes. The appropriate investigations for a newly diagnosed diabetic patient are:

 

1. HbA1c: To assess long-term glycemic control and confirm the diagnosis of diabetes.

 

2. Urine ACR (Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio): To screen for diabetic nephropathy, as microalbuminuria is an early sign of kidney damage.

 

4. Fundoscopy: To check for diabetic retinopathy and other microvascular changes in the eyes.

 

5. ECG: To screen for any cardiovascular complications, as diabetes increases the risk of heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Echocardiography: Not a routine screening test for diabetes unless there is a specific indication, such as suspected heart failure or structural heart disease.

 

6. Serum protein electrophoresis: Not indicated in the routine evaluation of diabetes and is used to diagnose conditions like multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a newly diagnosed diabetic patient, essential investigations include HbA1c, urine ACR, fundoscopy, and ECG to assess glycemic control, kidney function, eye health, and cardiovascular risk, respectively.

choices.text: SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age < 60 years

 

The ABCD2 score is a clinical tool used to predict the short-term risk of stroke after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The scoring system includes several factors that help assess this risk. Here’s why option A is the correct answer:

 

  • Age < 60 years: According to the ABCD2 scoring system, a patient who is aged 60 years or older scores 1 point, indicating a higher risk. Therefore, being younger than 60 does not contribute to an increased score, making it the correct choice for the exception in this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duration of TIA > 5 mins: In the ABCD2 score, the duration of the TIA is an important factor. TIA lasting 10-59 minutes scores 1 point, and TIA lasting more than 60 minutes scores 2 points. Duration less than 10 minutes would score 0. However, since the option simply says "Duration of TIA > 5 mins," without specifying how much longer, it's less clearly defined in this question, but generally longer durations imply a higher score.

 

Option C. SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg: High blood pressure at the time of TIA, defined as SBP ≥ 140 mm Hg or DBP ≥ 90 mm Hg, scores 1 point in the ABCD2 score.

 

Option D. Diabetes: The presence of diabetes in a patient who has experienced a TIA adds 1 point to the ABCD2 score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional D3-Dual TIA (within 7 days of first TIA), Imaging (MRI, DWI) were added to original score. However, all these perform very poorly in the light of recent evidences.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction


The flow-volume loop shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed central airway obstruction. This pattern suggests an obstruction that affects airflow both during inhalation and exhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fixed distal airway obstruction would not typically affect both phases of the loop.

 

Option C. Variable intrathoracic obstruction affects the expiratory phase more.

 

Option D. Variable extrathoracic obstruction affects the inspiratory phase more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

questions.text: A patient was treated with repeated doses of IV anti-emetic for severe vomiting. The patient now does not have vomiting but developed abnormal movements. What is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benzhexol

 

The patient likely received intravenous metoclopramide, a common anti-emetic, which can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as dystonia. Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, leading to repetitive movements or abnormal postures. This condition can be painful and distressing.

 

The treatment of choice for drug-induced dystonia is an anticholinergic medication. Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic drug that can effectively relieve dystonic reactions by blocking acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system, thereby restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is primarily used to treat motion sickness and postoperative nausea. It is not effective for treating dystonia induced by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option C. Levodopa: Levodopa is used to treat Parkinson's disease by increasing dopamine levels in the brain. It is not appropriate for treating acute dystonic reactions caused by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option D. Cyproheptadine: Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with antiserotonergic and anticholinergic properties. While it can be used for some dystonic reactions, it is not the first-line treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who develop dystonic reactions after receiving anti-emetic medications like metoclopramide, the most appropriate treatment is an anticholinergic drug such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). This helps alleviate the abnormal movements by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system.

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

 

The patient's presentation of polyuria and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/L) with hypernatremia (Na+ 155 mEq/L) is indicative of diabetes insipidus (DI). Given the history of total hypophysectomy, this is most likely central diabetes insipidus (CDI), where the pituitary gland no longer produces antidiuretic hormone (ADH, also known as vasopressin).

 

In CDI, the definitive treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP), a synthetic analog of ADH. Desmopressin helps to reduce urine output and correct hypernatremia by promoting water reabsorption in the kidneys. Since the condition is permanent due to the hypophysectomy, lifelong supplementation with desmopressin is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue: Discontinuing DDAVP after 2 weeks is not appropriate as the patient will continue to suffer from polyuria and hypernatremia due to the lack of ADH.

 

Option C. Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required: This option is incorrect as the patient's symptoms and lab findings clearly indicate the need for treatment.

 

Option D. Thiazides for 2 weeks: Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) to reduce urine output by increasing ADH sensitivity. However, in central diabetes insipidus, thiazides are not effective because the issue is the absence of ADH, not a problem with the kidneys' response to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

questions.text: Most common complication following percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bleeding

 

Explanation:

 

Bleeding is the most common complication of PTC, occurring in approximately 2-12% of cases. This is because:

  • The procedure involves needle puncture through liver tissue
  • The liver is highly vascular
  • Coagulopathy is common in patients with biliary disease
  • Multiple passes may be needed to access the biliary system
  • Both arterial and venous bleeding can occur

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangitis: While significant, it occurs less frequently than bleeding and is usually preventable with prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Option B. Hepatic Perforation: A rare complication that usually occurs during track dilation rather than initial access.

 

Option D. Pancreatitis: Unlike ERCP, PTC rarely affects the pancreas as it approaches the biliary system from above, making pancreatitis an uncommon complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Understanding the common complications of PTC
  2. Recognition that bleeding risk is inherent due to liver vascularity
  3. Appreciating the anatomical basis of complications
  4. Knowledge of preventive measures and risk assessment before the procedure

choices.text: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.text: Myasthenia gravis is associated with: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies target and destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This impairs the ability of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine to stimulate muscle contractions, leading to decreased synaptic transmission. The disease is characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly worsening with activity and improving with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased myosin: This option is not related to myasthenia gravis, which primarily affects the neurotransmitter receptors, not the muscle fiber proteins like myosin.

 

Option B. Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: While decreased acetylcholine release can affect neuromuscular function, in myasthenia gravis, the principal issue is the reduced effectiveness of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction due to antibody-mediated receptor damage, not a reduction in its release. Occurs with pre-synaptic blockers like bungarotoxin of krait causing reduced release of Ach rendering neostigmine ineffective.

 

Option C. Absence of troponin C: This is unrelated to the pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis. Troponin C is involved in the regulation of muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle, not neurotransmitter release or receptor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune disease characterized by Ab to postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Hence, treated with steroids and immunomodulators.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis. The symptoms started 3 hours ago. On examination, BP is 200/100 mm Hg. CT head is shown below. Which of the following should not be done in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate thrombolysis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient has presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis, and the CT scan shows evidence of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), indicating a hemorrhagic stroke. In the case of hemorrhagic stroke, immediate thrombolysis is contraindicated as it can worsen the bleeding. Thrombolytic agents, such as tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), are used to dissolve clots in ischemic strokes but can be harmful in hemorrhagic strokes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood pressure control: Managing high blood pressure is crucial in patients with hemorrhagic stroke to prevent further bleeding.

 

Option C. Clotting factor administration: In cases of hemorrhagic stroke, administering clotting factors or other agents to help control bleeding may be necessary.

 

Option D. Edema management: Managing cerebral edema is essential to reduce intracranial pressure and prevent further complications in hemorrhagic stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate thrombolysis should never be administered in patients with hemorrhagic stroke, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient's condition.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Palpitations
  2. Elevated BNP Troponins
  3. Regional wall motion abnormalities in echo
  4. ECG suggestive of myocarditis
  5. Low LVEF in echo
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4,5


Subclinical myocarditis may not present with symptoms like palpitations, but can show:

 

2. Elevated BNP/Troponins: Indicating myocardial injury.

3. Regional wall motion abnormalities: Seen on echocardiography.

4. ECG changes: Suggestive of myocarditis, such as non-specific ST-T changes.

5. Low LVEF: Indicative of impaired left ventricular function.

 

Other Option:
 

1. Palpitations are not a feature of subclinical myocarditis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Subclinical myocarditis can present with elevated cardiac biomarkers, regional wall motion abnormalities, ECG changes, and reduced LVEF, but not Palpitations, which is common in viral myocarditis.

 

Past common causes of myocarditis: Coxsackie virus types A and B.

 

 

Currently, Most common cause of myocarditis: Parvovirus B19 and HHV6.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG displays a rhythm with broad QRS complexes at a high rate, consistent with ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT is characterized by three or more consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of more than 100 beats per minute. The presence of such a pattern, particularly with a stable, repetitive form as seen in the ECG, strongly points to VT rather than other types of arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ECG: This option is incorrect as the ECG clearly shows an abnormal rhythm with broad QRS complexes, indicative of an arrhythmia originating below the AV node.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Ventricular fibrillation is characterized by irregular, chaotic electrical activity without identifiable QRS complexes, P waves, or T waves. The rhythm shown here is too organized and regular to be VF.

 

Option D. Misplaced leads: Misplaced leads causes positive p in aVR with normal intervals - R wave progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular tachycardia is identified by regular, broad QRS complexes at a rapid rate, distinct from the irregular pattern of ventricular fibrillation and the organized, narrower complexes typically seen with supraventricular rhythms and correct lead placement. Identifying VT on an ECG is critical due to its potential severity and the need for prompt treatment.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h
  2. Start injection ceftriaxone
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis
  4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

When managing a patient with fever and nuchal rigidity (suggesting possible meningitis), the correct order of steps is:

  1. Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h: Establishing IV access is the first priority to ensure hydration and create a route for medication administration.
  2. 4. Perform guarded lumbar puncture: The lumbar puncture should be performed early to collect CSF samples before antimicrobial therapy alters the CSF findings.
  3. Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis: Once the CSF is collected, it must be promptly sent for laboratory analysis to identify potential pathogens and guide targeted therapy.
  4. Start injection ceftriaxone: After CSF collection, empiric antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone should be initiated. This ensures that treatment doesn't interfere with CSF culture results while still providing timely antimicrobial coverage.

 

This sequence prioritizes obtaining diagnostic samples before starting antimicrobial therapy, which is critical for accurate diagnosis while not unduly delaying treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with a 10-year history of coarse facial features and progressive enlargement of the hands and feet. Laboratory evaluation revealed elevated IGF-1 and non-suppressible growth hormone levels after the 75 g glucose challenge test. A diagnosis of acromegaly is made. Which of the following drugs is preferred for the management of this condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lanreotide depot formulation

 

Acromegaly is a condition caused by excess growth hormone, often due to a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. The clinical features include coarse facial features and enlargement of the hands and feet. The diagnosis is confirmed with elevated IGF-1 levels and non-suppressible growth hormone levels following a glucose challenge test.

 

The first-line treatment for a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma is transsphenoidal surgery. However, when surgery is not immediately possible or has failed, medical management is necessary.

 

The preferred drugs in these situations are somatostatin receptor agonists, such as lanreotide, octreotide, and pasireotide. Lanreotide depot formulation is effective in reducing growth hormone levels and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Terlipressin: Incorrect. Terlipressin is primarily used in the management of acute variceal bleeding related to liver conditions, not in the treatment of acromegaly.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Incorrect. Ketoconazole is used in managing Cushing's syndrome in children due to its ability to inhibit cortisol synthesis. It is not indicated for the treatment of acromegaly.

 

Option D. Leuprolide: Incorrect. Leuprolide is a GnRH analogue used in the management of gynecological conditions such as fibroids and in prostate cancer. It is not effective in treating acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred medical management for acromegaly, especially as a bridge to surgery or when surgery has failed, is the use of somatostatin receptor agonists like lanreotide depot formulation.

questions.text: Interventional technique most commonly used for the management of acute ischemic stroke within the therapeutic window: [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mechanical thrombectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Mechanical thrombectomy is the primary endovascular intervention for acute ischemic stroke because:

  • It directly removes the occluding thrombus
  • Has a therapeutic window up to 6-24 hours in selected patients
  • Can be used with or without IV thrombolysis
  • Shows high recanalization rates
  • Improves functional outcomes in large vessel occlusions

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coiling: Used for treating aneurysms, not for acute stroke. It occludes vessels rather than opening them.

 

Option C. Basal stent placement: While stents may be used in chronic stenosis, they're not the primary treatment for acute stroke where immediate recanalization is needed.

 

Option D. Balloon Angioplasty: Though sometimes used in stroke treatment, it's usually adjunctive to thrombectomy and carries a risk of vessel damage or distal embolization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Understanding the role of mechanical thrombectomy in acute stroke
  2. Knowledge of therapeutic time windows for intervention
  3. Recognition of appropriate interventional techniques for different cerebrovascular conditions
  4. Appreciation of evidence-based approaches to acute stroke management

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Glucose

 

Rheumatoid pleural effusion, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, typically presents with low glucose levels, making high glucose the correct answer as it is not a characteristic found in such effusions. The low glucose in rheumatoid pleural effusion is due to increased metabolic activity of leukocytes and pleural cells which consume glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RA factor: The presence of RA factor (Rheumatoid factor) in pleural fluid is commonly seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody found in the blood of approximately 80% of adults with rheumatoid arthritis. Its presence in pleural fluid reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of the disease.

 

Option B. Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals in the pleural fluid are indicative of a long-standing effusion, which can occur in chronic rheumatoid pleuritis. These crystals form as the pleural fluid becomes more concentrated over time due to the chronic nature of the inflammation.

 

Option D. High LDH: High levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the pleural fluid are a common feature of exudative effusions, including those caused by rheumatoid arthritis. LDH is an enzyme present in most cells and is released into the pleural fluid when cells are damaged or destroyed, reflecting the inflammatory processes occurring in rheumatoid pleuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which one is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purulent conjunctivitis

 

Purulent conjunctivitis is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease. Instead, the conjunctivitis seen in Kawasaki disease is non-purulent and sterile, meaning it does not produce pus, and cultures are negative.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute, self-limited vasculitis that predominantly affects children. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease include the presence of fever for at least five days, along with at least four of the following five clinical features:

 

  1. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (conjunctivitis): This is a common feature in Kawasaki disease, but it is non-purulent (does not produce pus).
  2. Changes in the lips and oral cavity: This includes strawberry tongue (a red, bumpy tongue), erythema, and cracking of the lips.
  3. Polymorphous rash: A rash of various forms can be present.
  4. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Typically unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm in diameter.
  5. Changes in the extremities: This includes erythema of the palms and soles, edema of the hands and feet, and later desquamation (peeling) of the skin.

 

TOC - IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) ± Aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rash: A polymorphous rash is one of the key diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is another diagnostic criterion, usually unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm.

 

Option D. Strawberry tongue: Changes in the lips and oral cavity, including strawberry tongue, are diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is diagnosed based on a set of clinical criteria, including non-purulent conjunctivitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, and changes in the oral cavity such as strawberry tongue. Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

 

History is suggestive of chronic diarrhea with malabsorption occurring at the proximal small intestine (duodenum+ jejunum) causing protein loss (ascites, weight loss diarrhea), Osteoporosis (calcium, magnesium), and Iron deficiency (anemia).

 

All above in a young patient should hint towards the possibility of celiac disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TSH levels: While important for evaluating thyroid function, symptoms of hypothyroidism can overlap with some celiac disease symptoms (like fatigue), but the gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies strongly point towards a primary gastrointestinal cause.

 

Option B. C-peptide levels: C-peptide tests are used to evaluate insulin production levels and are more relevant in the context of diabetes management, not indicated here.

 

Option C. Urine sugar and ketone: This test is used to diagnose and manage diabetes by detecting sugar and ketones in urine, not related to the suspected diagnosis of celiac disease based on the provided symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient presenting with symptoms consistent with malabsorption, including gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies like iron and calcium, testing for celiac disease with an IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody test should be considered as a critical diagnostic step. This helps in confirming the diagnosis and facilitating appropriate dietary and medical management.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Celiac disease/Chapter 325

questions.text: A patient came to emergency with severe breathlessness. CXR is taken and shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pleural effusion

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray (CXR) of the patient shows a whiteout on one side with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side. These findings are indicative of a massive pleural effusion.

 

Pleural effusion: This condition results in the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, leading to lung compression and a shift of the mediastinum, including the trachea, away from the affected side. The presence of a large whiteout on the X-ray, along with the tracheal deviation to the opposite side, strongly suggests pleural effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: This condition would typically present with a hyperlucent (dark) area on the X-ray without lung markings, rather than a whiteout. It also generally causes a tracheal shift towards the opposite side, but the appearance on the X-ray would be different.

 

Option B. Consolidation: This condition involves filling of the alveoli with fluid or other material, leading to a whiteout appearance on the X-ray. However, it does not usually cause a significant tracheal shift.

 

Option C. Collapse: This condition, also known as atelectasis, would cause a shift of the trachea towards the affected side. It can present with a whiteout on the X-ray, but the tracheal deviation would be opposite to that seen in pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A massive pleural effusion is characterized by a whiteout on the chest X-ray with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a common malignancy in patients with HIV/AIDS. It is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and typically presents as painless or painful, violaceous (purple) lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral cavity. The image shows such a lesion on the palate, which is characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma. These lesions are vascular in nature and can vary in color from red to purple, often with a raised or nodular appearance. In HIV patients, Kaposi sarcoma is an AIDS-defining condition and is often seen in those with significant immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer usually occurs in sun-exposed areas of the skin and rarely affects mucous membranes. It typically presents as a pearly or waxy bump, not as multiple purple lesions.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: While melanomas can appear as pigmented lesions, they are usually black or brown and rarely present as multiple violaceous lesions in the oral cavity.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer can occur in the oral cavity but usually presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, firm, scaly plaque. It does not have the characteristic color and appearance of Kaposi sarcoma lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi sarcoma should be suspected in HIV patients presenting with violaceous lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. It is an AIDS-defining condition associated with HHV-8 infection.

questions.text: A patient presented with 2 Lisch nodules in the iris. What is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented, benign hamartomas found in the iris of the eye. They are highly specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), also known as von Recklinghausen disease. NF1 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors called neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and other neurological and ocular manifestations.

 

Key diagnostic feature:

 

  • Lisch nodules: These are melanocytic hamartomas and are considered a hallmark of NF1. Their presence, particularly when there are two or more, is diagnostic of NF1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This genetic disorder is characterized by the growth of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys, and heart. It is associated with other ocular findings such as retinal hamartomas, but not with Lisch nodules.

 

Option C. Sturge-Weber syndrome: This congenital disorder is associated with a port-wine stain birthmark, neurological abnormalities, and ocular issues like glaucoma, but not with Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Von Hippel Lindau syndrome: This is a genetic disorder that leads to the formation of tumors and cysts in different parts of the body, particularly the kidneys, pancreas, and central nervous system. It is not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lisch nodules in the iris is highly specific for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), making it a key diagnostic feature for this condition

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas report is as follows: pH 7.2, pCO2 81mm Hg, and HCO3 40 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

The arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows a pH of 7.2, which indicates acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is elevated at 81 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), indicating that the acidosis is due to a respiratory cause, as CO2 retention leads to respiratory acidosis.

 

The bicarbonate (HCO3) level is elevated at 40 mEq/L (normal range: 22-28 mEq/L). This elevation suggests that the kidneys are compensating for the respiratory acidosis by retaining bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions, indicating a chronic component to the respiratory acidosis.

 

In summary, the primary disturbance is respiratory acidosis, evidenced by the elevated pCO2, and the elevated bicarbonate suggests a compensatory response by the kidneys, characteristic of chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low pCO2, which is the opposite of the findings in this ABG report.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis would present with a low pH and a low bicarbonate level. However, in this case, the bicarbonate is elevated, not decreased, indicating the primary issue is not metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and elevated bicarbonate, but without the accompanying high pCO2. The presence of high pCO2 and low pH indicates the primary disturbance is respiratory, not metabolic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blood gas report showing low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory elevated bicarbonate indicates respiratory acidosis, often with a chronic component if the bicarbonate is significantly elevated.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings: Hb - 6.9g/dL, WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count, Serum calcium 13mg/dL, Creatinine 2.3mg/dL, Total protein 9g/dL, Albumin 2.4g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

 

The patient's symptoms, combined with lab findings of anemia, hypercalcemia, elevated total protein, and low albumin, along with osteolytic lesions, are indicative of multiple myeloma. The CRAB criteria (hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, and Bone lesions) support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


 

Option A. Metastatic breast cancer can present similarly but usually has a different primary site.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism causes hypercalcemia but not the full CRAB criteria.

 

Option D. Milk Alkali Syndrome causes hypercalcemia and renal impairment but not the protein abnormalities or osteolytic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and bone lesions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions as shown in the image. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

 

In this case, the patient presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and skin lesions. The chest x-ray reveals multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates, and the patient has a low CD4 count. These findings are significant for several reasons:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis can mimic tuberculosis, especially in HIV-positive patients. It causes disseminated disease with pulmonary involvement (multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates) and skin lesions. The presence of these lesions and a negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis further supports histoplasmosis, as this fungal infection is common in immunocompromised individuals with low CD4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis: While cryptococcosis can cause lung disease, it more commonly presents with central nervous system involvement, such as meningitis or meningoencephalitis. This patient does not exhibit neurological symptoms, making cryptococcosis less likely.

 

Option C. HIV with molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum causes umbilicated papules but does not lead to bilateral nodular infiltrates in the lungs. Thus, this diagnosis is unlikely given the chest x-ray findings.

 

Option D. HIV with tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is a common infection in HIV-positive patients and can present with similar symptoms and radiographic findings. However, the negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis in HIV-positive patients can mimic tuberculosis, presenting with pulmonary nodular infiltrates and skin lesions, especially in those with low CD4 counts.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient. Na+: 145 mEq/L, K+ 4 mEq/L Cl: 90 mEq/L HCO3: 20 mEq/L. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 35


The anion gap is calculated using the formula:

 

Anion Gap = Na−(Cl+HCO3)
 

Anion Gap=145−(90+20)=35

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anion gap is calculated as Na - (Cl + HCO3), and a high anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hereditary spherocytosis

 

Why Hereditary Spherocytosis is Correct: Hereditary spherocytosis is a condition characterized by the presence of spherical red blood cells that are prone to hemolysis. The spleen plays a significant role in the destruction of these abnormal red blood cells. Splenectomy is the treatment of choice for hereditary spherocytosis because it reduces hemolysis and anemia, leading to an improvement in the patient’s quality of life. It is typically recommended for patients with severe hemolysis or those who are transfusion-dependent.

 

  • Most Common Defect: The most common defect in hereditary spherocytosis is in the ankyrin protein.
  • Diagnostic Test: The investigation of choice for confirming hereditary spherocytosis is flow cytometry with eosin-5-maleimide. Historically, the osmotic fragility test was used.
  • Timing of Splenectomy: Splenectomy is generally performed after the age of 6 years and is indicated in patients with transfusion dependency anemia (majorly), severe anemia or growth retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G6PD deficiency: G6PD deficiency causes hemolysis primarily due to oxidative stress. Splenectomy is not beneficial because the spleen is not the primary site of red cell destruction in this condition.

 

Option B. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH involves intravascular hemolysis due to a defect in the red cell membrane. Splenectomy is not useful as the spleen is not involved in the hemolytic process.

 

Option D. Hairy cell leukemia: While splenectomy can sometimes be part of the management for symptomatic splenomegaly in hairy cell leukemia, it is not typically the first-line treatment. The primary treatment involves chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elective splenectomy is indicated in hereditary spherocytosis to decrease hemolysis and improve symptoms, particularly in patients with severe anemia or those who require frequent blood transfusions.

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleuritis with/without pleural effusion.

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion is the most common pulmonary manifestation in patients with SLE. This condition reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of SLE, which frequently affects serous membranes including the pleura. Pleural involvement in SLE typically presents as an exudative pleural effusion, often characterized by pleuritic pain and effusion that can be detected by physical examination and imaging studies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shrinking lung syndrome: is very rare occurring in 1% of patients. Some association with Anti-Ro/La antibodies seen. No correlation between disease activity, symptoms and antibodies.

 

Option B. Intra Alveolar hemorrhage and D. Interstitial inflammation: are not the most common presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion stands out as the most frequent pulmonary complication in SLE due to the disease’s propensity to inflame serous membranes. Accurate diagnosis and effective management of SLE and its pulmonary manifestations are crucial for improving quality of life and reducing morbidity in affected patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350 mg/dL, pH - 7.2, HCO3- 10 mEq/L, pCO2 – 25 mmHg. What is the metabolic abnormality? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic acidosis

 

The patient presents with a significantly acidic pH (7.2) and a low bicarbonate level (HCO3- = 10 mEq/L), indicating metabolic acidosis. The pCO2 is also reduced (25 mmHg), which suggests a respiratory compensatory mechanism aiming to increase acid excretion (by hyperventilating to blow off CO2) to counterbalance the acidosis.

 

This presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a common complication of diabetes that leads to metabolic acidosis, elevated blood glucose, and electrolyte imbalances due to the production of ketoacids from the breakdown of fats. The high blood sugar level of 350 mg/dL supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect as the low HCO3- and acidic pH point to acidosis, not alkalosis.

 

Option C. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect as the low pCO2 is a compensatory response to the metabolic acidosis, not the primary disorder.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect as this would involve an elevated pCO2, opposite of what is observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of high blood sugar and the reported ABG values, metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis, should be considered. This condition requires prompt recognition and management, typically involving fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, and electrolyte management to reverse the ketosis and acidosis.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of palms and soles. He was subsequently diagnosed to have lung cancer. Which of the following is responsible for hyperpigmentation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, a chronic smoker, presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles and was diagnosed with lung cancer. This clinical scenario suggests the presence of an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

In such cases, the excessive ACTH produced by the tumor can lead to Cushing's syndrome.

 

Additionally, ACTH has an intrinsic MSH (Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone) activity due to the shared precursor molecule, proopiomelanocortin (POMC). The MSH part within ACTH stimulates melanocytes, leading to increased melanin production and resulting in hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex. It does not play a role in causing hyperpigmentation in this context.

 

Option C. Neuropeptide Y: Neuropeptide Y is involved in various physiological processes, including regulation of appetite and stress responses, but not in causing hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Melanin: While melanin is the pigment responsible for skin color, its production is stimulated by MSH. Thus, MSH is the direct cause of increased melanin and subsequent hyperpigmentation in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ectopic ACTH production, such as with small cell lung cancer, hyperpigmentation occurs due to the MSH activity of ACTH, which stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old patient presented with fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was performed, and the reports are as follows: (FMGE JULY 2024)

 

  • Opening pressure – elevated
  • Appearance – cloudy
  • Cell count – 80 (70% PMNs)
  • Sugar – 35 mg/dL
  • Protein – 200 mg/dL

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Bacterial Meningitis

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of meningitis: fever, headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis from the lumbar puncture provides several key clues:

 

  • Elevated opening pressure, which is common in bacterial meningitis.
  • Cloudy appearance of the CSF, indicating a high number of cells or increased protein.
  • Cell count of 80 with 70% polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs), which is highly indicative of bacterial infection as it typically shows a neutrophilic predominance.
  • Low glucose level (35 mg/dL) and elevated protein level (200 mg/dL), which are consistent with bacterial meningitis due to the consumption of glucose by bacteria and increased protein from the inflammatory process.

 

Other Options:
